OperatorStr1: 1204 St. Olaf Av N,  P.O. Box 149

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Farmers Cooperative Association
1204 St. Olaf Av. N
P.O. Box 149
Canby, MN. 45220

For additional imformation please contact Peter Schmitz.

Risk Management Plan Executive Summary

The facility policy.

     Farmers Coop Assn owners, management, and employees are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia. Should an accidental release occur, our facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, and other authorities to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

Facility information.

     The primary activities at our facility is the srorage of anhydrous ammonia to be resold as nitrogen fertilizer for crop production.
     Our anhydrous ammonia storage tank and plant is located 1 mile South of the city of Canby, Mn on Hwy 75.
     At this location we have storage for 55,000 gallons of anhydrous ammonia which is delivered by tanker truck and stored in one 26,000 gallon storage tank and distributed to farmers in 1,000 gallon nurse tanks. The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia in storage would be 257,000 pounds in nurse tanks and main storage tank.

The worst case release scenario.

     The worst case scenario would be the release of the total contents of a 26,000 gallon storage tank of anhydrous ammonia in 10 minutes time with maximum quantity released being 114,000 pounds, which represents the volume of the storage tank at 85% capacity as limited by design standards. The distance to the end point (point of dispersion to 200 PPM) is 1.09 miles.

The alternate release scenario.

     The alternate release scenario is based on a most likely potential incident in which a release from a break in a three inck line with a duration of two minutes. The distance to the endpoint (point of dispersion to 200 PPM) is .78 miles.

The accidental release prevention program.

     This facility has implemented the rules and provisions of Minnesota Code of Agency Rules, "Storage and Handling

of anhydrous ammonia", 1513.0010-1513.1100.

Five year accident history.

     There has been no accidental release of any anhydrous ammonia in the past five years at any of our facilities that has caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility: nor to our knowledgem have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacutions, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

Emergency response program.

     Our facility has a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38. We have provided the state and local authorities with the emergency planning and Community Right to Know information as require under SARA Title (EPCRA) MN Section 312 Tier ll.

Planned changes to improve safety.

     Safety at Farmers Coop ASSN. facilities is an on-going process, with assessments and evaluations performed periodicly by organizations such as RCI to determine unsafe conditions and needed maintenance. At this time there are no additional specific recommendations planned for implementation at our anhydrous ammonia facility.
